results.title: Reflections: a Japanese folk tale
results.creator_credit: Thomas Smith and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: In a tale designed to probe the many facets of perception, a young man buys a box with a mirrored bottom and sees in it the face of his dead father. On opening the box his wife sees a young rival and a holy woman sees another holy woman. Are our own perceptions distorted by self-images? Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: A Painting for people
results.brief_description: Harold Freedman was employed by the Victorian Government to paint a large mural for the Spencer Street Railway Station on the one hundred years of transport, 1835-1935. Depicts the research, hundreds of drawings and the scope of work required to complete the first part of the mural. Narrated by Harold Freedman. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Much ado about nut things: problem solving, estimation
results.brief_description: An animated film introducing the concept of estimation and suggests ways to use it in problem solving. Also illustrates the use of the calculator in estimating solutions to problems. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Measure of man
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Tony Guy and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: A brief animated history of measurement which shows that measuring is arbitrary and that counting is not. The most important advantage of the metric system of measurement is the interrelationship of the units. Common metric units are whosn within their range of application.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Halas, Tony Guy and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films

results.title: The Living cell: an introduction
results.brief_description: Introduces the fundamental principles of cell biology, examining structures and biochemical processes that occur in all living cells. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Kalahari desert people
results.creator_credit: John Marshall, Robert Young, Dennis B. Kane, Nicholas Clapp and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Examines the social and cultural changes being made by the bushmen of southern Africa’s Kalahari Desert as modern influences change traditional patterns of living and they become farmer-herders after thousands of years of being hunter-gatherers.

results.title: An Italian family: life on a farm
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film presents geographic and cultural aspects of Italy with an account of one family living on a small farm, who, unlike many Italians seeking modernisation, avoid mechanisation in preference for a simple way of life. With collaboration by Edoardo Capolino.

results.title: Horse flickers
results.creator_credit: Bill Stitt, Jim Gruebel, Rhonda Raulston and Bill Stitt Productions
results.brief_description: Non-narrated children’s film in which a series of images of horses comes to life on a barn floor. They are composed of feathers and spangles, newspapers and sleeping bags, human beings and broomsticks and combine imagination, humour, whimsy and art. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Filbert and the melon cheater: subtraction with borrowing
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Introduces two digit subtraction problems, including those which require regrouping, through an animated story about the problems of an honest melon merchant. Filbert devises an accounting system called “dump a box” based on subtraction with borrowing to try to stop a melon thief. Suitable for upper primary level.
